0.14.text:
We've spent the past few
months talking about animals

2.72.text:
here on Crash Course, specifically
human animals, because...

6.16.text:
well, because humans...
we love talking about ourselves,

8.68.text:
and also because animals
are just really interesting.

11.25.text:
But it's high time that we talked
about the rest of the living world.

15.22.text:
Because I hate to break it to ya,
but most of the alive things on

20.49.text:
And by "most of the alive things"
I mean that these organisms

23.97.text:
make up two of the three
taxonomic domains of all life,

28.24.text: plus one of the four kingdoms.

30.10.text:
I'm talking about archaea,
bacteria and protists.

33.72.text:
With the exception of a few
protists, they're all unicellular,

37.03.text:
and they are, by far,
the most abundant

41.77.text:
More important, they lay
claim to the world's oldest

44.40.text:
and earliest living lineages,
dating back to the very first

48.01.text: twinkle of life on this planet.

50.28.text:
So by understanding
these three groups,

52.31.text:
you begin to truly understand
life on earth, its origins,

55.54.text:
and how everything that came after
them, including us, came to be.

59.65.text:
What's more, because
their heritage is so ancient,

61.86.text:
these organisms often
take weird, cool forms

64.50.text:
that don't look like life
as we think about it,

68.75.text:
Some not only live but thrive
in environments that would kill you,

72.54.text: me, and everything we hold dear.

74.63.text:
And others make their
living by invading organisms,

79.32.text:
Then there are those that do the
opposite, making life possible by,

82.21.text:
fixing nitrogen from the atmosphere
and helping animals digest food.

85.59.text:
Members of these groups have
names like Sailor's Eyeballs

87.92.text:
and Dog Vomit Slime Mold,
and they can take the shape

90.80.text: of rods, blobs, corkscrews or coils.

93.85.text:
Kinda like the doddering,
eccentric relatives

96.31.text:
you're forced to spend some holiday
with once a year, the archaea,

100.10.text:
bacteria and protists are
our oldest, oddest relatives.

103.85.text:
And it's about time
you got to know them.

113.88.text:
There's no denying it:
Every multicellular organism

118.03.text:
on this planet, whether it be
a mushroom or a vampire bat,

121.15.text:
evolved from a
single celled organism.

123.08.text:
And while some of these single
celled organisms evolved to populate

125.78.text:
the world as rhinos and strangler
figs, others found happiness

131.20.text:
and they haven't changed much
in the past few billion years.

134.10.text:
Today, nearly all unicellular
organisms are either archaea,

139.49.text:
Protists, you'll recall,
are eukaryotic organisms

141.77.text:
that make up the kingdom
Protista under the domain Eukarya.

146.00.text:
Bacteria and Archaea, meanwhile,
are their own prokaryotic domains.

149.88.text:
And I hope you haven't
forgotten this, the big difference

152.03.text:
between prokaryotes and eukaryotes
is that eukaryotic organisms,

156.26.text:
including you and the plants, and
fungi and animals that you know,

159.75.text:
have cells with a nucleus that
hold their genetic information,

165.19.text:
a nucleus or any
organelles to speak of.

167.63.text:
These two groups do have some
important things in common,

169.87.text:
like having plasma membranes
that are filled with cytoplasm,

172.57.text:
and ribosomes that contain
RNA and synthesize proteins.

175.90.text:
And they both have DNA that
carries the instructions

179.28.text:
But eukaryotic DNA comes in
strands in the form of chromosomes,

182.64.text:
while prokaryotic DNA is
found in rings called plasmids.

186.42.text:
So, again, and this
time with feeling:

189.20.text:
Protists are mostly single-celled
eukaryotic organisms.

192.68.text:
Archaea and bacteria are
single-celled prokaryotic organisms.

197.06.text:
The word "prokaryote" actually
means before the nucleus,

200.60.text:
which is a clue that prokaryotes
are an older form of life.

204.05.text:
And we literally cannot find
anything older than Archaea.

207.06.text:
The first Archaea fossils
date back 3.5 billion years ago

210.70.text:
I'm talking just a billion
years after the Earth formed

213.01.text:
and was still bombarded
by comets and meteors,

215.59.text:
not to mention fried
by UV radiation.

218.51.text:
But in the midst of all that,
archaea were just chillaxing.

221.98.text:
Earth's climate has calmed
down since then, so today

224.64.text:
archaea are found in some of the
world's most extreme environments:

228.10.text:
In underwater hydrothermal vents,
oil wells, volcanic hot springs,

234.96.text:
Archaea were probably
the earliest living things,

237.31.text:
and their adaptability is
probably what allowed them

239.70.text:
to take root in Earth's early,
kind of grody environment.

243.53.text:
One key group of the
archaea are the methanogens.

246.24.text:
These guys prefer more
moderate environments, like mud,

250.03.text:
swamps and your intestines,
but they derive their energy

252.58.text:
from hydrogen gas and carbon
dioxide, which is pretty cool

255.88.text:
and they emit methane
as their waste product.

260.16.text:
We know that waste as swamp gas,
and also, other kinds of gas.

264.82.text:
The other groups are extremophiles,
which not only tolerate

270.05.text:
The most famous of
these are the thermophiles,

272.66.text:
which live in temperatures
that would melt your face off.

275.00.text:
I mean, serious: Pyrolobus
fumarii, a species of archaea

277.91.text:
discovered in the late
1990's in a hydrothermal vent,

280.63.text:
live at temperatures
around 113 degrees celsius.

285.22.text:
Significantly above the
boiling point of water!

287.70.text:
Most organisms can't
take heat like that,

289.39.text:
because it causes their DNA to
unwind and their proteins to denature

294.36.text:
But thermophiles have evolved
adaptations that keep them stable

298.73.text:
There are also halophiles, or salt
lovers, which live in places

301.72.text:
like the Dead Sea or
the Great Salt Lake,

305.13.text:
Most halophiles breathe
oxygen and are heterotrophic,

307.26.text:
but there are some bizarro outliers,
like species that use sunlight

310.97.text:
to make energy,
but not like plants do

313.33.text:
they have light-harvesting
pigments in their membranes

316.29.text:
that react with light and enable
the cell to make ATP for energy.

320.88.text:
But despite their
alien-sounding ways of life,

324.20.text:
archaea really aren't
all that different from bacteria,

328.33.text:
In fact, archaea and bacteria
were classified together

332.04.text:
It was only when scientists realized
that they had some important

334.28.text:
genetic differences, like, in the
sequence of their ribosomal DNA

337.66.text: and the makeup of their RNA,

339.13.text:
that they were separated
into two domains.

341.56.text:
Bacteria are nearly as
ancient as archaea.

343.66.text:
Fossils show that they were
widespread about 1.5 billion

345.87.text:
years ago, but there's evidence
that they've been around

350.20.text:
Today, they make up the vast
majority of prokaryotes on Earth,

353.97.text:
and they're super slick when
it comes to adapting quickly.

358.92.text:
Think strep throat,
your staph infection,

361.28.text:
anything you've ever
taken an antibiotic for.

363.94.text:
But bacteria can
fend off antibiotics,

365.87.text:
and the ninjas in
your immune system,

367.91.text:
by garbling up their DNA from
one generation to another.

370.91.text:
They can randomly turn
genes on and off,

373.14.text:
creating unique genetic combination
as its population multiplies,

376.53.text:
keeping its host's immune system,
and drug-makers, on their toes.

380.35.text:
Like archaea, bacteria don't
reproduce sexually,

383.08.text:
but bacteria have devised a way
to pass their genetic material

385.99.text:
to their buddies, a little trick
called horizontal gene transfer.

389.25.text:
For example: you've heard
of antibiotic resistance, right?

392.15.text:
Well, horizontal gene transfer
is one reason for it.

395.24.text:
A strain of bacteria that has
genetic resistance to an antibiotic

398.30.text:
can pass some of its DNA,
and that drug resistance,

401.44.text:
to another strain, which
is why we're always in

403.91.text:
kind of an arms race with
the bacteria of the world.

406.48.text:
And of course bacteria
are incredibly diverse,

409.07.text:
with too many phyla to name,
more than two dozen.

411.34.text:
But one way of classifying them
is by their different kinds

413.37.text:
of cell membranes, which react
differently to a staining technique

418.48.text:
Gram positive bacteria
have thick cell membranes,

421.26.text:
and they're a huge group
that includes species

423.74.text:
that live individually like
staphlococcus and streptococcus,

427.35.text:
as well as some colonial
bacteria that are responsible

430.13.text:
for diseases like
leprosy and tuberculosis.

432.08.text:
There are lots of groups of
Gram-negative bacteria too,

436.36.text:
The biggest group
here are Proteobacteria,

439.05.text:
named after Proteus because
they take so many forms.

442.25.text:
These include bacteria that
make our lives possible

444.39.text:
by converting nitrogen in the
atmosphere into compounds available

447.25.text:
to plants, as well as
others that cause stuff

449.09.text:
like food poisoning and
Legionnaire's disease.

451.49.text:
Cyanobacteria, meanwhile,
are the only prokaryotes

453.79.text:
that use photosynthesis
to make their food,

456.43.text:
and they're some of the most
important members of aquatic

458.65.text:
food webs, providing microscopic
forage for all kinds

465.32.text: that you've no doubt heard of

466.97.text:
most are harmless, but a
couple of parasitic species

469.86.text:
are the culprits behind illnesses
like Lyme disease and syphilis.

472.96.text:
And speaking of sexually
transmitted diseases,

474.77.text:
the last major group of bacteria
worth mentioning are Chlamydias,

478.66.text:
which are strictly parasitic and
live only in animal cells.

482.20.text:
They're scumbags, obviously, and
are the leading infectious cause

485.02.text:
of blindness in the world,
as well as that eponymous infection

488.93.text:
of the urethra that makes
me kind of want to,

491.71.text:
cross my legs,
just thinking about it.

493.66.text:
So, Archaea have managed
to make a nice,

495.78.text:
multi-billion-year living
by surviving in weird,

497.86.text:
out of the way places, and
bacteria have developed ways

500.66.text:
to pass their DNA
without sexual reproduction.

503.62.text:
But you know who's a hot
freakin' mess? Protists.

506.88.text:
Evolutionarily, they're the
youngest of the three,

509.35.text:
having evolved from bacteria
around 1.7 billion years ago,

513.03.text:
and in a lot of ways
they're more sophisticated.

514.87.text:
For starters, they're eukaryotic,
but also, some are multicellular,

520.03.text:
and a few kinds can
even reproduce sexually.

522.43.text:
But their domain is a big crap
circus, because some protists

526.11.text:
seem to be more closely
related to plants or animals

531.93.text:
So scientists tend
to talk about them

533.09.text: based on what else they resemble.

535.20.text:
There are Protozoa,
which are kinda animal-like,

539.69.text:
and fungus-like ones, including
the tastefully-named Slime Molds.

543.38.text:
The one thing all
of these have in common

545.37.text: is they need to live somewhere wet:

547.23.text:
in a bog, or in your body,
or in a snow bank, wherever.

550.73.text:
Protozoa are actually really cool
because they're like tiny animals.

554.99.text:
so they have to eat other
stuff in order to live.

557.91.text:
And because they need to eat,
they've got mouthparts,

560.23.text:
or at least mouth-part sorts
of things, and they can

562.99.text:
move around by using all kinds
of really cool structures.

565.80.text:
Some have flagella, the whip-like
tails, to propel them

567.94.text:
through the water, or cilia,
little hair-like structures

570.61.text:
that work like oars,
and some move around

573.15.text:
with a kind of blobby
amoeba-like motion.

575.76.text:
I say amoeba-like
because the protozoans

578.03.text: that move this way are amoebas.

579.95.text:
And speaking of amoebas, some
protozoans are parasitic.

583.16.text:
You've probably heard of amoebic
dysentery: that's caused by amoebas.

586.77.text:
Malaria is caused
by this little guy,

590.91.text:
While African Sleeping Sickness
is caused by Trypanosoma brucei,

595.44.text:
Moving on to the plant-like
protists, which are algae.

602.52.text:
because they use different
kinds of chlorophyll molecules.

604.80.text:
Some are unicellular,
like tiny diatoms,

606.68.text:
which have a hard
shell made of of silica.

608.19.text:
But the amazing thing
about single-celled algae

610.13.text:
is that they can get
really honkin' huge.

613.10.text:
For example, ladies and
gentlemen, cast your gaze

615.50.text:
upon the Sailor's Eyeball,
thought to be the biggest

621.62.text:
Also known as "bubble algae,"
it lives on the sea floor

624.49.text:
in tropical oceans and can
grow up to 5 centimeters across.

628.24.text: How is that thing one cell?

630.91.text:
Anyway, you already know
multicellular types of algae,

633.31.text:
aka seaweed. They're closely
related to land plants,

636.41.text: as you can tell by looking at them,

638.72.text:
and they're generally grouped in
to red, green and brown varieties,

641.79.text:
although these all have their
unicellular forms as well.

644.44.text:
The green algae are
probably what gave rise to

646.56.text:
land plants about
475 million years ago.

649.51.text:
They're the most
abundant and diverse,

651.86.text:
and they have chloroplasts
very much like land plants,

655.11.text:
so they can only
live in shallow water

656.61.text:
because they need
a lot of sunlight.

658.03.text:
Red algae is able to
live at greater depths

659.97.text:
and has an extra pigment
in it called phycoerythrin,

663.04.text:
which gives its chlorophyll
a boost in deeper waters.

665.82.text:
And brown algae is what most of the
seaweed you see in the ocean is.

670.91.text:
They're the largest and most
complex of the multicellular algae.

674.67.text:
Finally, we have our
fungus-like protists,

677.31.text:
which include the
delightful slime molds.

679.68.text:
They absorb nutrients
from their environment

681.35.text:
and produce fruiting
bodies like fungi,

683.47.text:
but even though they
look like piles of barf,

685.49.text:
they can actually move
around like an amoeba

689.67.text:
Slime molds can be
pretty easy to spot

692.39.text:
like this charming species
which, in all seriousness,

695.17.text: is known as Dog Vomit Slime Mold.

697.11.text:
You heard me.
These organisms are so freakin'

699.10.text:
screwed up that scientists
couldn't think of a better name

701.30.text: for it than Dog Vomit Slime Mold.

703.36.text:
Like I said. They're old.
They're odd. Get used to it.

707.19.text:
Thanks for watching this episode
of Crash Course Biology.

709.66.text:
If you want to catch up on
anything you're a little fuzzy on:

713.52.text:
Thanks, of course,
to all the people

714.77.text:
that helped put this
episode together.

716.15.text:
And if you have any
questions for us, please

718.01.text:
Facebook, Twitter,
or the comments below.
